title: Can you share your experiences with teaching? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is so much to share. I've been doing this for nearly half my life - it is both the most rewarding and most frustrating thing I’ve ever done. My experiences with teaching have been quite varied. I started in a job teaching AP Chemistry to some of the hardest-working kids on the planet. They were absolutely amazing, and they pushed me to my limits. That was great. But things change. Even though I still work in the same building, the city and culture has changed around me. I now have massive attendance and apathy problems, and the average grades in my class have plummeted. I spend lots of time on behavior problems and remediation. One thing I’ve learned from this transition is that I can’t teach students I don’t see. Quite simply, skipping a class is something I cannot help with. I’ve tried so many strategies to increase student attendance, and nothing has worked. I don’t know how to solve this particular problem, but until it gets solved, my failure rate will remain high. It’s tragic, particularly because most of the students who have terrible attendance aren’t terrible students - many are quite bright. But they perform poorly because they miss so much instruction. I’ve also learned that parental involvement is critical. I had to stop giving homework several years ago (I still give almost none) because so few students turned it in that it ended up lowering everyone’s grade. Now, you might say “well, good…those kids deserve a lower grade”, but there’s a problem with that statement (well, several actually). First is this: why aren’t they doing the homework? Is it laziness? Inability? Homelessness? It could be any one, and there’s not much way to know for sure. Second is this: if too many students fail, you lose the class (and potentially your job). When everyone is failing, why try? The class must be impossible. Third: it’s a logistical nightmare when students are regularly absent. Fourth: students don’t care so much about poor grades. Telling one of my students they might fail does almost nothing - many students have failed very frequently and so don’t care anyway. Fifth: Cheating is not only rampant but viewed as the norm. Everyone cheats on homework, either by using other students’ answers or by using the internet. So homework went the way of the Dodo. But then students don’t get as much practice, as much repetition, or as much mastery. All of this taught me another important lesson: “School Quality” is a joke. Look at any city, and you’ll see amazing scores for the affluent suburbs and lousy scores for the poor inner city neighborhoods. But is this a reflection on the job the school is doing or the ability and support systems of the kids coming in? Believe me, it’s the latter. Some of the most amazing teachers I’ve ever met work in really poorly-performing schools. They look like terrible teachers if you judge them by their SAT scores. But judge them by the difference they make to kids, and they are invaluable. It’s just that the measurement of this difference is difficult to say the least. So instead, we say “Wow! Look at the SAT scores at Suburban High School #12. They are so high - that school must be doing something right!” They are doing something right - they’re educating the children of affluent, well-educated adults in a low crime, low poverty, low homelessness environment. But chances are their teachers and administrators are no different in quality to any other school. Last thought: What you tolerate, you promote. We hear that one a lot. So just stop tolerating tardiness and it will go away…right? Unfortunately, that only works if everyone stops tolerating tardiness (or whatever it is you want to stop). That means principals, all teachers, and most importantly, parents. It’s nearly impossible to stop a negative behavior when parents take the blame for it. I see it all the time - parents making excuses for their kids when the kids are clearly able to do better. And the result is nearly always the same, too - the behavior increases and the performance goes down. But I still love my job…part of the time. There are days when there’s nothing I’d rather be doing. But there are days when 60% of my students are skipping…and then I want to quit. I know I’m practically wasting a day, and I’ll have to do lots of extra work to help kids who are skipping my class. Both of those things suck your will to do your best.

Always know your material wellAlways have more material than you think you will needAlways have extra or fun things for your students to doAs a teacher you are coach, mentor, mother, father, disciplinarian, super hero, and model for your students. Some days you will feel like a super her / coach. Other days you will be exhausted, frustrated, and feel like all you did was discipline. It is still worth it.

I haven’t done in-class teaching for quite a while since 2014 and I have a mix of positive and negative experiences. I’ll share my positive experiences here: What is Jimmy Y. Zhong like as a graduate tutor of psychology at NUS from 2011 to 2013? As for the negative experiences, I’ll keep them private.
